head.title: Not Quite All-American, Bertelsmann Is Big on U.S.

hedline.hl1: Not Quite All-American, Bertelsmann Is Big on U.S.

abstract.p: Bertelsmann AG chairman Thomas Middelhoff, trying to make point that media company is global rather than German, schedules first employee meeting in US at Radio City Music Hall; photo (S)

block.p: Thomas Middelhoff, chairman of Bertelsmann A.G., the media conglomerate, would like to make one thing clear: Bertelsmann is no longer a German company. ''We are really the most global media company,'' he says, with its BMG music unit and Random House based in the United States.

To emphasize that point, Mr. Middelhoff did not hire the Rockettes, but he did rent Radio City Music Hall. On Sept. 15, he will meet with the 3,000 employees of Bertelsmann's businesses in New York. Bertelsmann, based in the small German town of Gutersloh, holds similar meetings each year in Munich, Paris and Barcelona, but this is the first in the United States.

''The employees are getting: 'What is the personality of our C.E.O.? For what is he staying and fighting? What to him is important?' '' Mr. Middelhoff said. The event will last two hours, including a video of interviews with Bertelsmann employees, a speech by Mr. Middelhoff and a question-and-answer session. No Rockettes, but there will be representatives of the company's German workers council.
